org.gearvrf.debug

Class GVRConsole

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gearvrf.GVRHybridObject
      • org.gearvrf.GVRPostEffect
        • org.gearvrf.debug.GVRConsole
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Closeable, java.lang.AutoCloseable, GVRShaders<GVRPostEffectShaderId>

    public class GVRConsole
extends GVRPostEffect
    A debugging console for VR apps. Lets you put text messages on both or either eye. This can be a useful way to get feedback on your code as you exercise it, instead of having to use logcat asynchronously.

    You can have multiple consoles. The point of this is to let you write different messages to the left eye than to the right eye: putting multiple consoles on the same eye will make both hard/impossible to read.

    Known Limitations:

    • Is implemented as a "post effect" so the messages are written before lens distortion is applied.
    • Does not do line wrap. Long messages will be truncated.
    • Does not support Java escape characters like \n or \t.

    • Constructor Detail

      • GVRConsole

        public GVRConsole(GVRContext gvrContext,
                  GVRConsole.EyeMode startMode)
        Create a console, specifying the initial eye mode.
        Parameters:
        gvrContext - The GVR context.
        startMode - The initial eye mode; you can change this via setEyeMode(EyeMode)

      • GVRConsole

        public GVRConsole(GVRContext gvrContext,
                  GVRConsole.EyeMode startMode,
                  GVRScene gvrScene)
        Create a console, specifying the initial eye mode and the GVRScene to attach it to. This overload is useful when you are using GVRContext.getNextMainScene() and creating your debug console in GVRScript.onInit(GVRContext).
        Parameters:
        gvrContext - The GVR context.
        startMode - The initial eye mode; you can change this via setEyeMode(EyeMode)
        gvrScene - The GVRScene to attach the console to; this is useful when you want to attach the console to the next main scene.

    • Method Detail

        public void writeLine(java.lang.String pattern,
                      java.lang.Object... parameters)
        Write a message to the console.
        Parameters:
        pattern - A String.format(String, Object...) pattern
        parameters - Optional parameters to plug into the pattern

      • getTextColor

        public int getTextColor()
        Get the text color.
        Returns:
        The current text color, in Android Color format

      • setTextColor

        public void setTextColor(int color)
        Set the text color.
        Parameters:
        color - The text color, in Android Color format. The alpha component is ignored.

      • getTextSize

        public float getTextSize()
        Get the current text size. The default text size is somewhat bigger than the default Android Paint text size: this method returns the current text as a multiple of this component's default text size, not the standard Android text size.
        Returns:
        The current text size factor.

      • setTextSize

        public void setTextSize(float newSize)
        Set the text size.
        Parameters:
        newSize - The new text size, as a multiple of the default text size.

      • getEyeMode

        public GVRConsole.EyeMode getEyeMode()
        Get the current eye mode, or where the console messages are displayed. This may be the value passed to the constructor, but you can also change that at any time with setEyeMode(EyeMode).
        Returns:
        The current eye mode.

      • setEyeMode

        public void setEyeMode(GVRConsole.EyeMode newMode)
        Set the current eye mode, or where the console messages are displayed. Always 'edits' the list of post-effects; setting the mode to GVRConsole.EyeMode.NEITHER_EYE means this component will not affect render times at all.
        Parameters:
        newMode - Left, right, both, or neither.
